image.altText: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall sit, surrounded by their children, all the women holding bouquets

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch always wanted his media empire to stay in the family, but he could never commit to an heir. Despite having six children, only three were ever considered viable successors.

title.children: 'It's like The Godfather': How Rupert Murdoch's children spent their lives in competition

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch gestures with both hands while speaking.

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch's retirement is a momentous media moment that could lead to big shifts in the media and political landscapes in Australia and other parts of the English-speaking world.

title.children: The media's most influential mogul is retiring. What does it mean for the news, politics and the media landscape?

image.altText: A sign adorns the building where mining company Rio Tinto has their office in Perth, Western Australia, November 19, 2015.

props.synopsis: Three years after the Juukan Gorge blasts, mining giant Rio Tinto says it has apologised to traditional owners and is working with them after damage to another ancient heritage site.

title.children: Rio Tinto blast damages ancient rock shelter near iron ore mine in WA's Pilbara

image.altText: An aerial image of a power station with white towers and steam, against a blue-pink horizon.

props.synopsis: A high-stakes fight over the future of a failed Australian coal mine descends into acrimony, as a major power station takes legal action against consultancy Deloitte.

title.children: Power fight turns nasty as US-controlled plant decries efforts to 'destroy' its rights

image.altText: A ribbon bound version of Australia's constitution with a photo of the Australian outback in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia will vote on whether to make a change to its constitution next month. But what is this document? And what is the proposed change? We break it down for you here, and show you what the constitution would look like if the Voice referendum is passed.

title.children: Here's how the Australian Constitution would change if the Voice referendum is passed

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks at a podium at the National Press Club

props.synopsis: No campaigner Jacinta Nampijinpa Price told the National Press Club last week there are no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation on Indigenous Australians. RMIT ABC Fact Check takes a look.

title.children: We fact checked Jacinta Nampijinpa Price on the negative impacts of colonisation. Here's what we found

image.altText: a woman in front of a sold sign out the front of an apartment block with a real estate agent

props.synopsis: Almost one in six sellers in Sydney's high-construction neighbourhoods are losing money, some as much as $100,000 for their lifetime investment, with interest rate squeeze pushing buyers to sell up for a loss.

title.children: Ella spent her life savings on a Sydney unit — it sold for $100,000 less five years later

image.altText: A woman holds her stomach which has a baby in it and leans on a tree.

props.synopsis: Working full-time, recently married and pregnant, Maria and her partner never thought they wouldn't be able to find a home. But amid the rental crisis that's plaguing Australia, living in a tent was their only option.

title.children: Priced out of the rental market and six months pregnant, Maria's only option was to live in a tent

image.altText: Lachlan Murdoch and Rupert Murdoch sitting together at Day 10 of the US Open held at the USTA Tennis Center on September 5, 2018

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Malcolm Turnbull says Lachlan Murdoch is 'more ideological than his father', King Charles visits fire-damaged Notre-Dame. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Homes in New Zealand's Queenstown have been evacuated and a number of schools were forced to close after the city was hit by flooding. Queenstown Lakes District Council Mayor Glyn Lewers has declared a state of emergency due to the impact of heavy rainfall in the area over 24 hours. "Several flooding and debris events have been identified and we're continuing to contact affected people including evacuating over 100 people," Mr Lewers says. The lower South Island has received significant rainfall in parts over the past few days, and Bluff at the southern-most end of the South Island declared a state of emergency on Thursday. Schools in central Queenstown are closed, according to their websites, and the New Zealand roads authority has warned of road closures across the lower South Island.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: State of emergency declared at popular New Zealand holiday destination

children.content: Homes in New Zealand's Queenstown have been evacuated and a number of schools were forced to close after the city was hit by flooding.
Queenstown Lakes District Council Mayor Glyn Lewers has declared a state of emergency due to the impact of heavy rainfall in the area over 24 hours.
"Several flooding and debris events have been identified and we're continuing to contact affected people including evacuating over 100 people," Mr Lewers says.
The lower South Island has received significant rainfall in parts over the past few days, and Bluff at the southern-most end of the South Island declared a state of emergency on Thursday.
Schools in central Queenstown are closed, according to their websites, and the New Zealand roads authority has warned of road closures across the lower South Island.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's former prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, has also weighed in on Rupert Murdoch's resignation, saying he's not suprised by the news. "He's built a vast global media empire, and no doubt the business pages will give him credit for that. But he has done enormous damage to the democratic world and, in particular, to the United States. "The anger-tainment ecosystem that Fox News, above all, has created in the US has left America angrier and more divided than it's been at any time since the civil war. It is sought in order to keep its ratings up, it is sought to enrage Americans, divide Americans, and divide them against each other." Mr Turnbull says he doesn't believe much will change under the helm of the media mogul's son, Lachlan Murdoch. "Knowing both of them over a very long period of time, my impression is that Lachlan is more ideologically conservative than Rupert. "I think Rupert has always been fascinated by power — he's drawn to it like a moth is to a flame — and so he's enjoyed exerting the power that he has over the political system. And Rupert's politics have evolved to be broadly right-wing, I would say. "But, I agree, I think Lachlan is, if anything, more ideological than his father. So, I don't think there's going to be any change for the better, that's for sure."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Malcolm Turnbull says Lachlan Murdoch is 'more ideological than his father'

children.content: Australia's former prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, has also weighed in on Rupert Murdoch's resignation, saying he's not suprised by the news.

"He's built a vast global media empire, and no doubt the business pages will give him credit for that. But he has done enormous damage to the democratic world and, in particular, to the United States.

"The anger-tainment ecosystem that Fox News, above all, has created in the US has left America angrier and more divided than it's been at any time since the civil war. It is sought in order to keep its ratings up, it is sought to enrage Americans, divide Americans, and divide them against each other."
Lachlan is one of Rupert Murdoch's six children.
(Getty: Adrian Edwards)
Mr Turnbull says he doesn't believe much will change under the helm of the media mogul's son, Lachlan Murdoch.
"Knowing both of them over a very long period of time, my impression is that Lachlan is more ideologically conservative than Rupert.

"I think Rupert has always been fascinated by power — he's drawn to it like a moth is to a flame — and so he's enjoyed exerting the power that he has over the political system. And Rupert's politics have evolved to be broadly right-wing, I would say.
"But, I agree, I think Lachlan is, if anything, more ideological than his father. So, I don't think there's going to be any change for the better, that's for sure."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A woman has told the BBC that comic-actor Russell Brand exposed himself to her when she was working in the same building at the BBC in 2008. He was recorded laughing with his co-presenter who said Brand "showed his willy to a lady", the BBC reports. The BBC says it is urgently looking into issues raised by all the allegations made against Brand. You can read the full story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woman says Russell Brand exposed himself to her and laughed about it on radio

featuredLink.title: Woman tells BBC Russell Brand exposed himself to her and laughed about it on the radio

image.altText: An illustrated image of Norman Bates with half his face as an android

props.synopsis: Five years after researchers created a psychopathic algorithm to demonstrate bias and discrimination in artificial intelligence, we're still learning its lessons.

title.children: 'Norman still haunts me': Why warnings from the world's first 'psychopath AI' are as relevant as ever

image.altText: A child wears a facemask and steers a boat on the water with the red-orange sky behind them.

props.synopsis: For the first time in three years, Australians face the risk of significant bushfires. Are we any better prepared for big fires than we were before Black Summer?

title.children: El Niño has ramped up bushfire risks again, but Australia's in a better place now than before Black Summer

image.altText: Police at a command post with crime scene tape across the front

props.synopsis: Police recover at least one body after fire destroys a home in Gnowangerup, in WA's Great Southern region.

title.children: Police recover body from house destroyed by fire in country WA

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch gestures in front of a sign that reads "Fox"

props.synopsis: Australia's share market is tipped to lose value this morning, after losses on Wall Street overnight, while Rupert Murdoch has stepped down as Fox chairman.

title.children: Rupert Murdoch steps down as Fox chairman, losses on Wall Street overnight, local market tipped to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to today's markets live blog. The ASX futures suggest the local market will lose more value in this morning's trading session. US markets all took losses overnight. The Dow Jones lost a touch over 1%, the Nasdaq lost 1.8%, and the S & P500 lost 1.6%. And if we look at the global stock market indices, the board is a sea of red, as they say, except for the volatility index (which is up 15%). So we'll see what happens locally today. Remember, yesterday Australia's market closed down by 1.4%, at 7,065.2 points, which was the lowest level since July 11. Rupert Murdoch has announced he is stepping down as chairman of Fox Corp and News Corp, and handing the reins to his son Lachlan. There'll be a lot of news on that topic today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to follow Wall Street lower

children.content: Good morning and welcome to today's markets live blog.
The ASX futures suggest the local market will lose more value in this morning's trading session.
US markets all took losses overnight. The Dow Jones lost a touch over 1%, the Nasdaq lost 1.8%, and the S
And if we look at the global stock market indices, the board is
a sea of red
, as they say, except for the volatility index (which is up 15%).
So we'll see what happens locally today.
Remember, yesterday Australia's market closed down by 1.4%, at 7,065.2 points, which was the lowest level since July 11.
Rupert Murdoch has announced he is stepping down as chairman of Fox Corp and News Corp, and handing the reins to his son Lachlan.
There'll be a lot of news on that topic today.

image.altText: Zelenskyy standing with US senators.

props.synopsis: After seeking to shore up international support at the United Nations, Mr Zelenskyy comes to Washington on a crosstown blitz including meetings with military leaders and Mr Biden and an evening address at the National Archives museum.

title.children: Zelenskyy faces tough crowd in US but Biden approves half a billion in fresh military aid

image.altText: A black and white photo of an unseen woman holding up a hand to protect herself.

props.synopsis: The Supreme Court gives NSW Police extraordinary powers to recover and relocate an at-risk teenager by flying her to a safe house in Sydney.

title.children: Welfare officials considered the risk of harm to 16yo 'Emma' so great, they asked to charter a plane to rescue her

image.altText: A photo of a woman laughing in a hospital bed with her son and daughter next to her

props.synopsis: The former nurse was diagnosed with an aggressive form of motor neurone disease and given months to live. Her dying wish was to save lives — and she did in an Australian first.

title.children: Marlene chose to end her life with dignity. But her death saved four others

image.altText: Wind farms at dusk with the sun setting behind them on the coast line

props.synopsis: The debate still rages about dealing with climate change and, close to home, Australia's energy transition, which is under way but accompanied by increasing pain and problems, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese government faces an uphill road and angry locals as it drives change to renewables

image.altText: An anxious-looking black Labrador curled up on a couch with a zebra-striped blanket.

props.synopsis: There's growing recognition that animals can develop mental and behavioural disorders like humans, but there are important factors to consider when treating these issues.

title.children: Prozac has helped Brian the labrador's anxiety. But treating pets' mental health can be complicated

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch, an older man with glasses, reads newspapers in the back of a car.

props.synopsis: His son Lachlan Murdoch will become the sole chair of News Corp following his decision to step down.

title.children: 'The time is right': Rupert Murdoch steps down as chairman of Fox Corporation and News Corp

image.altText: Methamphetamine pictured next to pillows

props.synopsis: The men, including the grandson of a former WA Premier, were minor players in a plan to import $159 million worth of methamphetamine into Australia, a Perth court hears.

title.children: Three men were 'cannon fodder' in plot to import 99kg of meth hidden in latex pillows, court hears

image.altText: brahman

props.synopsis: It's three times more likely than foot-and-mouth disease, but Australia still has no vaccine bank for lumpy skin disease.

title.children: With the threat of lumpy skin disease looming, where is Australia's access to vaccines?

image.altText: Imran Khan walks through a dense crowd of men as he tries to leave a courtroom while wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: As former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan languishes in a jail cell near Islamabad and his supporters fall silent in fear, his family welcomed the ABC inside his heavily guarded home in Lahore.

title.children: Imran Khan was rich, famous and powerful. Now he’s in a tiny, filthy prison cell in Pakistan

image.altText: A Collingwood AFL player pumps his fists as he celebrates a goal.

props.synopsis: After being sidelined with injury since early August, Nick Daicos is included in Collingwood's line-up for the grand final qualifier, as GWS prepares to contain the young Magpies star.

title.children: Giants aim to 'minimise the damage' as Daicos makes Magpies return in preliminary final

image.altText: A coach speaks to Melbourne AFL players during a 2023 premiership match.

props.synopsis: Richmond opts for one of the most experienced assistants in the AFL as it finally fills the role vacated by three-time premiership coach Damien Hardwick.

title.children: 'A great fit for the club': Tigers throw support behind Hardwick's long-term successor

image.altText: A platypus on a riverbank

props.synopsis: Plans to build more homes near the Illawarra's Macquarie Rivulet were rejected in 2021, and conservationists say a local platypus population will be threatened if the decision is overturned.

title.children: Fears platypus 'stronghold' could be destroyed if housing expansion south of Sydney goes ahead

image.altText: Australian surfer Owen Wright covers his face as he is overcome by emotion after winning the Tahitit Pro while wearing a safety

props.synopsis: High-profile head injuries are forcing surfers to rethink the decades-old stigma around wearing helmets, particularly when taking on death-defying waves.

title.children: Surfing is one of the only extreme sports where helmets are rarely worn — but that's starting to change

image.altText: A young man in an orange cap, at night, talking to media, with reflective light obscuring his face.

props.synopsis: Oscar Piastri is 11th in the drivers' championship, with six top 10 finishes and a best of fourth at the British Grand Prix.

title.children: Armed with upgrades and a new contract, Piastri sets sights on Japan

image.altText: Julie Bishop speaks to the media

props.synopsis: A 24-year-old man is remanded in custody, charged with attempted murder and assault. The ANU says it was not given relevant information before the violent incident.

title.children: 'I was so angry': ANU chancellor Julie Bishop says university was in the dark ahead of stabbings

image.altText: A smiling blonde woman teaches a class. She is making notes on a whiteboard.

props.synopsis: Chloe McLaren was born in Scotland and loved the snow and freezing cold. But when she moved from Brisbane for a placement in the sweltering outback, she realised she did not want to leave.

title.children: This young teacher signed up to help fill the outback skills gap. It was a perfect match

image.altText: A woman on a train films herself

props.synopsis: A few weeks ago Sabrina Bahsoon could travel on London's public transport system without being noticed, but in just a few short weeks she's become "Tube Girl", whose self-shot dancing videos on her commute have sparked a viral social media trend.

title.children: Who is 'Tube Girl'? How a viral sensation is sparking conversations about self-confidence
